title: How the U.S. election process differs from others around the world
description: The decentralized system of election management in the United States has few parallels. But results in many countries can take time to finalize.
author: Amanda Coletta
excerpt: The decentralized system of election management in the United States has few parallels. But results in many countries can take time to finalize.
text: The U.S. presidential election draws the kind of international interest and news coverage often reserved for elections much closer to home — as the world turns its attention to a process of which some parts have few parallels elsewhere.U.S. elections are distinct in their use of an electoral college, the long length of the campaign and rules around campaign financing. In some countries, such as France and Australia, voting takes place not on a workday but on the weekend.
html:
The U.S. presidential election draws the kind of international interest and news coverage often reserved for elections much closer to home — as the world turns its attention to a process of which some parts have few parallels elsewhere.

U.S. elections are distinct in their use of an electoral college, the long length of the campaign and rules around campaign financing. In some countries, such as France and Australia, voting takes place not on a workday but on the weekend.
